abstract.para: This guide describes basic workflows for working with packages on &obs;. It covers checking out a package from an upstream project, creating patches, branching a repository, and more.

sect1.title: Target Audience
sect1.para: This document is intended for interested users and developers who want to build packages from source code for different distributions. Basic knowledge of Linux and usage of the command line is recommended.
sect1.remark: toms 2017-08-03: Add some links to basic tutorials etc.?

sect1.title: Conceptual Overview
sect1.para: Created in 2005, the &obs; (&obsa;) is a generic system to build and distribute packages or images from source code in an automatic, consistent and reproducible way. &obsa; can create images and installable packages for a wide range of operating systems (&suse;, Debian, Ubuntu, RedHat, Windows, etc.) and hardware architectures (&x86;, &amd64;, &zseries;, &ppc; etc.).

sect2.title: Package Specification
sect2.para: To create a package in &obsa;, you need a package specification which contains the following information:

formalpara.title: Metadata
formalpara.para: The package name and the description are mandatory. Other data such as the version, the license, the upstream URL is optional.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: Packages depend on other packages to function properly. There are two types of requirements: build requirements and installation requirements.

listitem.para: Build requirements are dependencies which are needed during the build process in &obsa;. For example, a C++ program needs a C++ compiler.
Installation requirements are dependencies which are needed when installing the final package.

formalpara.title: A Package List
formalpara.para: To successfully install and remove a package with all its contents, the package manager needs to know which files and directories belong to which package.

sect2.para: For RPM-based operating systems such as &opensuse;, &sle;, or &rhel;, all the information above is included in a file with the file extension .spec.

sect2.title: Build Hosts and Packages
sect2.para: The &obsa; server provides a Web interface and an API. The API is used by the &osccmd; command line tool.

To build the package, the back-end creates a sandbox with the respective distribution on demand. This sandbox is isolated from the rest of the host system. Depending on the &packspec; (on RPM-based systems, this is a spec file), other packages are downloaded and installed prior to building.

The build process itself executes all the instructions inside the &packspec;. If the build is successful, the files which belong to the package are installed into the sandbox. From those sandboxed files, the final RPM package is created and moved into a download area (the download repository).
The package is then publicly available and can be installed. In the case of an RPM package for a &suse;-based system, you would use &yast; or Zypper as the installation tool.
Other services around &obsa; (like the notification server, mirror interface etc.) are relatively specific in purpose and therefore of lesser importance for this guide.
The schematic in shows the components in context.

sect2.title: Projects and Packages
sect2.para: In &obsa;, packages are organized in projects. A single project can contain several packages and usually serves a specific organizational purpose. Generic access control, related repositories, and build targets (operating systems and architectures) are all defined at the project level.
Projects can also have other projects (subprojects) to structure work. They are isolated from their parents project and can be configured independently.

Each project name is separated by colons. For example, in the &opensuse; Build Service, packages for fonts are collected in the project M17N:fonts which is a subproject of M17N. Packages for the Python programming language are available in the devel:languages:python project which is a subproject of devel:languages which itself is a subproject of devel.

As a user, you will normally build packages in your home project, available in &obsa; as home:USERNAME. Home projects serve as a personal working area in &obsa; to define build targets, upload, build, and download packages. Users are also permitted to create subprojects f temporary subprojects to work on other people's packages.
Sometimes, you will see the obs://DOMAIN/PROJECT notation. The obs:// schema is a shorthand to abbreviate the long URL and needs to be replaced by the real &obsa; instance URL.

sect1.title: Requirements for Working with &osccmd; on the Command Line
sect1.para: Before you work with &obs;, make sure you fulfill the following requirements.

listitem.para: To work with &obs;, install the &osccmd; command line tool from your preferred distributions or from the &obsa; project openSUSE:Tools. The tool runs on any modern Linux system and is available for different distributions, such as CentOS, Debian, &sle;, &opensuse;.
For &suse; related systems, install the osc package with the zypper command (replace DISTRIBUTION with your distribution):
For other systems, use your preferred package manager.

As an alternative, use the &appimg; file. An &appimg; file is a packaged application which can run on many distributions. Download the file, save it in your ~/bin directory, and make the file executable.
Make sure you have a minimum of 1 GB of disk space available. The &osccmd; command builds all packages locally under &oscbuildpath; and caches downloaded packages under &oscbuildcache;.

sect1.title: Covered Scenarios
sect1.para: This guide assumes:

listitem.para: At least a passing familiarity with version control systems such as Git and Subversion (SVN). Not only will Git be used for some aspects of this guide, many &obsa; concepts are modeled after their Subversion (SVN) equivalents.
You are using the &osbs; at . If you are using another &obsa; instance, some commands may differ.
You have an account on an &obs; instance.
An RPM-based operating system like &opensuse; or &sle;.
A customized system as shown in .

sect1.para: In all examples, we use:

listitem.para: A user on a local machine (you) who will be called &exampleuser; who builds packages on their own machine.
An &obsa; user who will be called &obsuser1; and their home &obshome1; on the &obs;. This person is the same as the system user &exampleuser;, that is, you.
An &obsa; user &obsuser2; and their home &obshome2; on &obs;. This person will act as a collaborator.
An example upstream open source project available at . This project is used as an example and contains source code in the C++ programming language.

sect1.para: This guide describes the following common tasks:

listitem.para: Setting up a home project using the &obsa; Web UI.
Creating packages from a basic project hosted on &gh;.
Patching source code without touching the original source.
Branching a project, making changes, and submitting back the changes to the original project.
Integrating the download repository into your system and how to install your built package.

sect1.title: Setting Up Your Home Project for the First Time
sect1.para: This section shows how to set up your home project after creating an &opensuse; account.

When you log in to your home project for the first time, it will be empty. To build packages, you need to select build targets (operating systems and architectures) first. Build targets are defined project-wide and every package in a project is built for each build target. However, you can disable build targets for a specific package.
To set up a home project, do the following:

procedure.title: Adding Global Build Targets to Your Home Project

step.para: Log in to the &obs; instance.
Click the Home Project link in the upper right corner.
Click the Repositories tab, then the Add Repositories link.
Select the distributions you want to build for.

&obsa; shows several Linux distributions. For &suse; distributions, we recommended to activate at least &tw; and the latest &leap; release. If you like, you can also mark one of the openSUSE Backports for SLE 12 which enables package builds for &sle;.
When you select a distribution, &obsa; will show a message that it has successfully added it to your home project.
Click the Overview tab to see the available build targets on the right side.

sect1.para: If you need more build targets, you can repeat the procedure above. It will be added to the list of existing build targets.

If you need to fine tune your build targets, click the Repositories tab, find the respective build target, and click the Edit repository link. This will show the available architectures and additional package repositories you can add.

sect1.title: Creating a New Project
sect1.para: This section covers how to create packages from a simple C++ project hosted on &gh; (the upstream project). We assume that this project contains source code which you want to package for different &suse; distributions.

note.title: Check the License First
note.para: Before building, go to the homepage of the upstream project and check the license first.

For example, in the &osbs;, you must only redistribute packages which are available under an open source license. If you are submitting to &opensuse;, the source code will be checked for license compliance. If your package does not abide by an open source license, it will be rejected.
You can find a list of already used licenses in &obsa; at . For more details and a comparison of open source licenses in general, see .

sect1.para: To create a package from the upstream project, do the following:

step.para: Set up your project as shown in .
Open a shell. Choose or create a directory on your system in a partition that has enough space to hold the package sources.
Check out your home project:
This will create an empty &obsworkdir1; directory in the current directory.
Create a new package inside your local working directory:
Get the pristine source code of the upstream project and save it in &obsworkdir1;/&gitproject;.
Download a TAR archive of the sources.

In our example, the project is hosted on &gh; and this URL can be used: . If there is no published release of a project yet, download the latest sources by clicking the Clone or download button and then the Download ZIP link.
Create the &packspec;. This file contains metadata and build instructions.
In this example, we are building an RPM for &opensuse;. For RPM-based distributions, we create a spec file. The skeleton of such a spec file looks like this:
step.screen:
# # spec file for package &gitproject; # # -- Copyright omitted --
Name: &gitproject; Version: &gitprjvers; Release: 0 License: GPL-3.0 Group: TBD Summary: Example tool for OBS Url: &gitupstream1; Source: &gitproject;-%{version}.tar.gz BuildRequires: gcc BuildRequires: cmake BuildRoot: %{_tmppath}/%{name}-%{version}-build
%description
%prep %setup -q -n %{name}-%{version}
%build
%install
%files %defattr(-,root,root,-) %doc README LICENSE *.txt %{_bindir}/*
%changelog

formalpara.title: The Header
formalpara.para: Metadata like package name, version, release, license, the RPM group, a brief summary, the upstream URL, and the name of the source file.

formalpara.title: Build Requirements
formalpara.para: Lists dependencies on other packages which are needed for building. The listed packages are downloaded and installed before building the package.

formalpara.title: The Description Section
formalpara.para: Illustrates the purpose of the package and gives a comprehensive explanation.

formalpara.title: The Preparation Section
formalpara.para: Prepares the sources for building. This usually includes unpacking them with the %setup macro and patching them using the %patch macro. (However, patching is not shown here. For more information, see .)

formalpara.title: The Build Section
formalpara.para: Contains Shell commands or RPM macros for building the package.

formalpara.title: The Install Section
formalpara.para: Contains Shell commands or RPM macros which create directories or copy files to the installation location.

formalpara.title: The Files Section
formalpara.para: Lists all files and directories which belong to the package. Documentation-related files are marked with %doc and are automatically installed in the default documentation directory.

formalpara.title: The Changelog Section
formalpara.para: This section is usually empty. Instead, &obsa; searches for a file with the extension .changes. If such a file exists in the project directory, it will automatically be included as a changelog. The changelog file itself contains a high level overview of the history of the package.

sect1.title: Patching Source Code
sect1.para: This section describes how to patch an upstream project. We use the same project as shown in .
There are different reasons for patching a package:

formalpara.title: You Do Not Have Permission to Commit Upstream
formalpara.para: Often, you cannot commit changes directly to the upstream project. If you send changes to the upstream project, they may be integrated late or even be rejected.

listitem.para: Patch files allow making changes while keeping source code pristine and also allow independence from an upstream project's release cycle, coding style, and internal workings.

formalpara.title: To Apply Security and Bug Fixes or Distribution-specific Fixes
To Change the Source Code, So It Builds on &obsa;
To Improve Security and Traceability
formalpara.para: A pristine source code in &obsa; is easier to check for changes than a modified one. The check is usually done with a checksum (MD5 or SHA).

formalpara.title: To Improve Structure and Consistency
formalpara.para: From an organizational point of view, it is better when changes are separated from the source code. With the changes inside the patch file, everybody can see what was changed and which files changes were applied to.

sect1.title: Branching a Package
sect1.para: This section describes how to collaborate between projects. You can branch any package in &obsa; into any project that you have write permission for. By default, new branches will be created as a subproject of your home project. Such default branches have names beginning with &obsbranch1;.
There are different reasons to branch a package:

listitem.para: To modify the source code, building it, trying the effect of the changes, and submitting back changes to the original project. Usually, you use this workflow when you do not have write permissions of a project.
To make changes without affecting the original project.
To apply temporary changes to try out a different path of development.

sect1.para: User &obsuser2; has finished the task now and the submit request is assigned to &obsuser1;. User &obsuser1; can decide whether to:

formalpara.title: Accept the Submit Request
formalpara.para: The changes from user &obsuser2; will be integrated into the &obshome1; project. The accepted submit request will be closed. To make further changes, &obsuser2; needs to create a new submit request.

formalpara.title: Decline the Submit Request
formalpara.para: The changes from user &obsuser2; are not integrated into the &obshome1; project.

listitem.para: For example, reasons to decline a submit request are build errors or style issues. When declining submit request, the reviewer will usually give a reason. User &obsuser2; can then correct their submission using a new submit request that supersedes the previous one, disagreeing and reopen the request, or accepting the refusal and revoke the request.
The submitter will see declined requests still as open requests, because users see it as task on the &obsa; Web UI.

sect1.title: Installing Packages from &obsa;
sect1.para: &obsa; provides a place which contains all the distribution-specific and architecture-specific versions of successfully built packages. When you create a package in your &obsa; home project, all successfully built packages will appear under the &obsdnlurlhome1; URL.

However, this is only true for the home project itself and manually created subprojects but not for subprojects created as a result of branching a package. Branched projects are not published by default. If you need the build results though, download the binaries manually with osc getbinaries.

For example, if you have enabled the &tw; distribution, all packages for Tumbleweed will appear under the URL &obsdnlurlhome1;/openSUSE_Tumbleweed. This download repository is used as an installation source for Zypper or &yast;.
